name: Cook the Book: Canned Tuna
description: I love a good tuna sandwich, and I make them at home all of the time. I always buy the fanciest imported Italian tuna packed in olive oil, usually the one that comes in the best looking can. Some mayo,...
recipeIngredient: 3 1/2 pounds very fresh tuna, with skin, bones, and any stringy blood vessels removed

recipeInstructions.text: Cut the tuna into chunks as close to the size of the jars as you can manage. Stuff the chunks of tuna into the jar and fill the gaps in the jars with small bits of tuna, still leaving 1 inch of headspace at the top. Do not overfill the jars or your seals will fail.

Add 1/2 teaspoon of salt to the top of each jar and pour enough olive oil to cover the fish, leaving 3/4 inch of headspace at the top of the jar. Using a butter knife, press the tuna away from the sides of the jar so the oil can fill any air pockets between the chunks of tuna.
Wipe the rims, set on the lids, and screw on the bands fingertip tight. (If you put a dab of white vinegar on the cloth you use to wipe the rims, the oil will clean off better.)
